[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/75/Anorectum.gif)](/wiki/File:Anorectum.gif)

Anatomy of the anus and rectum

**Defecation** is the final act of [digestion](/wiki/Digestion "Digestion"),
by which organisms eliminate solid, semisolid, or liquid [waste](/wiki/Waste
"Waste") material from the [digestive tract](/wiki/Digestive_tract "Digestive
tract") via the [anus](/wiki/Anus "Anus").

[Humans](/wiki/Human "Human") expel [feces](/wiki/Human_feces "Human feces")
with a frequency varying from a few times daily to a few times
weekly.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] Waves of [muscular contraction](/wiki/Muscle "Muscle") (known as
_[peristalsis](/wiki/Peristalsis "Peristalsis")_) in the walls of the
[colon](/wiki/Colon_\(anatomy\) "Colon \(anatomy\)") move fecal matter through
the digestive tract towards the [rectum](/wiki/Rectum "Rectum"). Undigested
food may also be expelled this way, in a process called _egestion_.

[Open defecation](/wiki/Open_defecation "Open defecation"), the practice of
defecating outside without using a [toilet](/wiki/Toilet "Toilet") of any
kind, is still widespread in some [developing
countries](/wiki/Developing_countries "Developing countries"), for example in
India.[1]

## Description

### Physiology

The [rectum ampulla](/wiki/Rectal_ampulla "Rectal ampulla") (anatomically
also: _ampulla recti_) temporarily stores fecal waste. As the waste fills the
rectum and expands the rectal walls, [nervous system](/wiki/Nervous_system
"Nervous system") stretch receptors in the rectal walls stimulate the desire
to defecate. This urge to defecate arises from the reflex contraction of
rectal muscles, relaxation of the [internal anal
sphincter](/wiki/Internal_anal_sphincter "Internal anal sphincter"), and an
initial contraction of the skeletal muscle of the [external anal
sphincter](/wiki/External_anal_sphincter "External anal sphincter"). If the
urge is not acted upon, the material in the rectum is often returned to the
colon by [reverse peristalsis](/wiki/Reverse_peristalsis "Reverse
peristalsis"), where more water is absorbed and the faeces is stored until the
next mass peristaltic movement of the transverse and descending colon. If
defecation is delayed for a prolonged period the fecal matter may harden,
resulting in [constipation](/wiki/Constipation "Constipation"). If defecation
occurs too fast, before excess liquid is absorbed, [diarrhea](/wiki/Diarrhea
"Diarrhea") may occur.[2]

When the rectum is full, an increase in intra-rectal pressure forces apart the
walls of the [anal canal](/wiki/Anal_canal "Anal canal"), allowing the fecal
matter to enter the canal. The rectum shortens as material is forced into the
anal canal and peristaltic waves push the feces out of the rectum. The
internal and external anal sphincters along with the [puborectalis
muscle](/wiki/Puborectalis_muscle "Puborectalis muscle") allow the feces to be
passed by muscles pulling the anus up over the exiting feces.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Defecation is normally assisted by taking a deep breath and trying to expel
this air against a closed glottis ([Valsalva maneuver](/wiki/Valsalva_maneuver
"Valsalva maneuver")). This contraction of expiratory [chest](/wiki/Chest
"Chest") muscles, [diaphragm](/wiki/Diaphragm_\(anatomy\) "Diaphragm
\(anatomy\)"), abdominal wall muscles, and [pelvic](/wiki/Pelvis "Pelvis")
diaphragm exerts pressure on the digestive tract.
[Ventilation](/wiki/Ventilation_\(physiology\) "Ventilation \(physiology\)")
at this point temporarily ceases as the lungs push the chest diaphragm down to
exert the pressure. Thoracic [blood pressure](/wiki/Blood_pressure "Blood
pressure") rises and as a reflex response the amount of blood pumped by the
heart decreases. Death has been known to occur in cases where defecation
causes the blood pressure to rise enough to cause the rupture of an
[aneurysm](/wiki/Aneurysm "Aneurysm") or to dislodge blood clots (see
[thrombosis](/wiki/Thrombosis "Thrombosis")). Also, in releasing the Valsalva
maneuver blood pressure falls; this, coupled with standing up quickly to leave
the toilet, can result in a blackout.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] [3]

During defecation, the external sphincter muscles relax. The anal and
[urethral sphincter](/wiki/Urethral_sphincter "Urethral sphincter") muscles
are closely linked. Experiments by Harrison Weed at the [Ohio State University
Medical Center](/wiki/Ohio_State_University_Medical_Center "Ohio State
University Medical Center") have shown they can only be contracted together,
not individually, and that both show relaxation during urination.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] This
explains why defecation is frequently accompanied by
[urination](/wiki/Urination "Urination").

### Voluntary and involuntary control

Defecation may be involuntary or voluntary. Young children learn voluntary
control through the process of [toilet training](/wiki/Toilet_training "Toilet
training"). Once trained, loss of control, called [fecal
incontinence](/wiki/Fecal_incontinence "Fecal incontinence"), may be caused by
physical injury, nerve injury, prior surgeries (such as an
[episiotomy](/wiki/Episiotomy "Episiotomy")),
[constipation](/wiki/Constipation "Constipation"), [diarrhea](/wiki/Diarrhea
"Diarrhea"), loss of storage capacity in the [rectum](/wiki/Rectum "Rectum"),
intense fright, [inflammatory bowel disease](/wiki/Inflammatory_bowel_disease
"Inflammatory bowel disease"), [psychological](/wiki/Psychological
"Psychological") or [neurological](/wiki/Neurological "Neurological") factors,
[childbirth](/wiki/Childbirth "Childbirth"), or [death](/wiki/Death
"Death").[4]

## Posture

Main article: [Human defecation postures](/wiki/Human_defecation_postures
"Human defecation postures")

The positions and modalities of defecation are [culture-
dependent](/wiki/Culture#Cultures_by_region "Culture"). [Squat
toilets](/wiki/Squat_toilet "Squat toilet") are used by the vast majority of
the world, including most of Africa, Asia, and the Middle East.[5] The use of
sit-down [toilets](/wiki/Toilet "Toilet") in the [Western
world](/wiki/Western_world "Western world") is a relatively recent
development, beginning in the 19th century with the advent of indoor
plumbing.[6]

## Health aspects

Attempting forced expiration of breath against a closed airway (the [valsalva
maneuver](/wiki/Valsalva_maneuver "Valsalva maneuver")) is sometimes practiced
to induce defecation while on a [toilet](/wiki/Toilet "Toilet"). [Cardiac
arrest](/wiki/Cardiac_arrest "Cardiac arrest")[7] and other cardiovascular
complications[8] can in rare cases occur due to attempting to defecate using
the valsalva maneuver. Valsalva retinopathy is another pathological syndrome
associated with the Valsalva maneuver.[9][10]

## Society and culture

### Anal cleansing after defecation

Main article: [Anal cleansing](/wiki/Anal_cleansing "Anal cleansing")

The [anus](/wiki/Anus "Anus") and [buttocks](/wiki/Buttocks "Buttocks") may be
[cleansed](/wiki/Anal_cleansing "Anal cleansing") after defecation with
[toilet paper](/wiki/Toilet_paper "Toilet paper"), similar paper products, or
other absorbent material. In many cultures, such as Hindu and Muslim, water is
used for anal cleansing after defecation, either in addition to using toilet
paper or exclusively. When water is used for anal cleansing after defecation,
toilet paper may be used for drying the area afterwards.

### Mythology and tradition

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Caganer_back.png/160px-
Caganer_back.png)](/wiki/File:Caganer_back.png)

[](/wiki/File:Caganer_back.png "Enlarge")

The _[caganer](/wiki/Caganer "Caganer")_ is a defecating figurine in Spanish
[Nativity scenes](/wiki/Nativity_scene "Nativity scene")

Some peoples have culturally significant stories in which defecation plays a
role. For example:

  * In an [Alune](/wiki/Alune_people "Alune people") and [Wemale](/wiki/Wemale "Wemale") legend from the island of [Seram](/wiki/Seram "Seram"), [Maluku Province](/wiki/Maluku_Islands "Maluku Islands"), [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia "Indonesia"), the mythical girl [Hainuwele](/wiki/Hainuwele "Hainuwele") defecates valuable objects.[11]
  * One of the [traditions of Catalonia](/wiki/Traditions_of_Catalonia "Traditions of Catalonia") ([Spain](/wiki/Spain "Spain")) relates to the _[Caganer](/wiki/Caganer "Caganer")_ , a [figurine](/wiki/Figurine "Figurine") depicting the act of defecation which appears in [nativity scenes](/wiki/Nativity_scene "Nativity scene") in [Catalonia](/wiki/Catalonia "Catalonia") and neighbouring [areas with Catalan culture](/wiki/Catalan_Countries "Catalan Countries"). The exact origin of the _Caganer_ is lost, but the tradition has existed since at least the 18th century.[12]
